Award.AwardTitle: Combinatorial link homologies and their applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project deals with structures and applications of combinatorial link homologies. The first theme of the proposed research is link homologies and embeddings of Lie algebras. It is known that certain embeddings of Lie algebras induce state sum formulas for the corresponding polynomial link invariants. The Principal Investigator (PI) will study how to "lift" such formulas to the categorifications of these link polynomials. The main motivation for this is a potential explicit categorification of the Kauffman polynomial using certain additional structures on the Khovanov-Rozansky homology. The second theme is twistings in link diagrams and the Khovanov-Rozansky homology. Krasner simplified the Khovanov-Rozansky chain complex of a two-strand twisting, which has led to new topological and structural results about the Khovanov-Rozansky homology. The PI will further study applications of this simplified chain complex. The final theme of this project is the spanning tree model. The PI will study potential applications of the explicit spanning tree model for the odd Khovanov homology of knots recently discovered by Roberts, Jaeger and Manion.

In the late 1990s, Khovanov pointed to a new direction in the quantum invariant approach to low-dimensional topology. His work showed that, instead of working inside a linear space or a module, one should work inside a category. This way, the construction will lead to homological invariants which retain more topological information than the polynomial invariants. Such homological invariants are called categorifications of the corresponding polynomial invariants. Khovanov categorified the Jones polynomial and, with Rozansky, the HOMFLY-PT polynomial. Experts have used these categorifications to prove topological theorems that were only accessible by geometric analysis before. Among these, the best known is Rasmussen's combinatorial proof Milnor's Conjecture. The goal of this project is to further expand the scope of the categorification approach to knot theory by better understanding existing categorifications, constructing new categorifications and finding new applications of these categorifications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Quantum topology is the study of low-dimensional topology using algebraic methods closely related to quantum physics. It began with the definition of the Jones polynomial, which was later generalized to the HOMFLYPT, Kauffman, Reshetikhin-Turaev polynomials for links and the quantum invariants for 3-manifolds.

In the late 1990s and early 2000s, Khovanov pointed to a new direction in quantum topology. His work demonstrates that, instead of working inside a linear space or a module, one can also work inside a category. This way, the construction will give stronger homological link invariants instead of polynomial invariants. These homological invariants retain more topological information than the corresponding polynomial invariants, and are called categorifications of the corresponding polynomial invariants. Khovanov defined the Khovanov homology that categorifies the Jones polynomial. Later, he and Rozansky defined  the sl(N) and HOMFLYPT versions of the Khovanov-Rozansky homology that categorify the HOMFLYPT polynomial.

In this project, the PI focused on two types of module structures of the Khovanov-Rozansky homologies. First, in the construction of the Khovanov-Rozansky homology, one can introduce a new variable "a" in several different ways. Such constructions give either an equivariant version or a transverse version of the Khovanov-Rozansky homology. These versions of the Khovanov-Rozansky homology are Q[a]-module. Second, all versions of the Khovanov-Rozansky homology are naturally modules over the polynomial ring generated by the components of the link.

The PI showed that the Q[a]-module structure of an equivariant Khovanov-Rozansky homology is equivalent to the corresponding Lee-Gornik spectral sequence. He also defined the sl(N) version of the transverse Khovanov-Rozansky homology, which strengthens the sl(N) Khovanov-Rozansky homology and generalizes the HOMFLYPT homology. The Q[a]-module structure of the sl(N) transverse homology indicates to close relations between the sl(N) and the HOMFLYPT versions of the Khovanov-Rozansky homology.

The PI also studied the module structure of the HOMFLYPT homology over the polynomial ring generated by the components of the link. He proved that:

1. The Hilbert polynomial of this module determines the number of components of the links.

2. The projective dimension of this module provides an obstruction to split links.

3. If the base field is the field of two elements, then this module detects unlinks.

As a byproduct of the above work, the PI also extended the definition of the HOMFLYPT homology to general directed graphs. He proved that the Krull dimension of this generalized homology is the cycle packing number of the directed graph. Based on this result, the PI directed an undergraduate student, Thomas Riggs, to write a PYTHON program that uses Macaulay2 to compute the cycle packing number of small directed graphs. For this work, Riggs was awarded a Data Master Fellowship by the George Washington University.
